  1. An atom in an excited energy state may emit a photon of the appropriate energy to spontaneously move to a lower energy state.
  1. Because an atom is modeled as a system consisting of an electron and a nucleus, a change in the energy state of an atom corresponds to a change in the interaction energy between the electron and the nucleus.

tags.label: 15.3.A.3
tags.description: 15.3.A.3: Transitions between two energy states of an atom correspond to the absorption or emission of a photon of a single frequency and, therefore, a single wavelength.

tags.label: 15.3.A.4
tags.description:
15.3.A.4: Atoms of each element have a unique set of allowed energy levels and thereby a unique set of absorption and emission frequencies. The unique set of frequencies determines the element's spectrum.
  1. An emission spectrum can be used to determine the elements in a source of light.
  1. An absorption spectrum can be used to determine the elements composing a substance by observing what light the substance has absorbed.
  1. Energy level diagrams are commonly used to visually represent the energy states of an atom.

tags.label: 15.3.A.5
tags.description: 15.3.A.5: Binding energy is the energy required to remove an electron from an atom, causing the atom to become ionized. An atom in the lowest energy level (ground state) will require the greatest amount of energy to remove the electron from the atom.
15.4: Blackbody Radiation

tags.label: 15.4.A
tags.description: 15.4.A: Describe the electromagnetic radiation emitted by an object due to its temperature.

tags.label: 15.4.A.1
tags.description: 15.4.A.1: Matter will spontaneously convert some of its internal thermal energy into electromagnetic energy.

tags.label: 15.4.A.2
tags.description: 15.4.A.2: A blackbody is an idealized model of matter that absorbs all radiation that falls on the body. If the body is in equilibrium at a constant temperature, then it must in turn emit energy.

tags.label: 15.4.A.3
tags.description:
15.4.A.3: A blackbody will emit a continuous spectrum that only depends on the body's temperature. The radiation emitted by a blackbody is often modeled by plotting intensity per unit wavelength as a function of wavelength.
  1. The distribution of the intensity of a blackbody's spectrum as a function of temperature cannot be modeled using only classical physics concepts. A blackbody's spectrum is described by Planck's law, which assumes that the energy of light is quantized.
  1. The peak wavelength emitted by a blackbody (the wavelength at which the blackbody emits the greatest amount of radiation per unit wavelength) decreases with increasing temperature, as described by Wien's law. Relevant equation: \(\displaystyle{{{\lambda }_{\max }}=\frac{b}{T}}\)
  1. The rate at which energy is emitted (power) by a blackbody is proportional to the surface area of the body and to the temperature of the body raised to the fourth power, as described by the Stefan-Boltzmann law. Relevant equation: \(\displaystyle{P=A\sigma {{T}^{4}}}\)
15.5: The Photoelectric Effect

tags.label: 15.5.A
tags.description: 15.5.A: Describe an interaction between photons and matter using the photoelectric effect.

tags.label: 15.5.A.1
tags.description: 15.5.A.1: The photoelectric effect is the emission of electrons when electromagnetic radiation is incident upon a photoactive material.

tags.label: 15.5.A.2
tags.description:
15.5.A.2: The emission of electrons via the photoelectric effect requires a minimum frequency of incident light, called the threshold frequency.
  1. Light that is incident on a material and is at the threshold frequency or higher will induce electron emission, regardless of the number of photons that strike the material.
  1. The energy of the emitted electrons is not dependent on the number of photons that are incident upon the material, which provides evidence that light is a collection of discrete, quantized energy packets called photons.

tags.label: 15.5.A.3
tags.description:
15.5.A.3: The maximum kinetic energy of an emitted electron is related to the frequency of the incident light and the work function of the material, \(\displaystyle{\phi }\).
  1. The work function of a material is the minimum energy required to emit an electron from atoms in the material.
  1. The maximum kinetic energy of an emitted electron is given by the equation \(\displaystyle{{{K}_{\max }}=hf-\phi }\).
  1. In a typical experimental setup to demonstrate the photoelectric effect and determine the work function of a metal, two metal plates are placed in a vacuum chamber and connected to a variable source of potential difference. One of the plates is illuminated by monochromatic light that causes electrons to be ejected and the potential difference between the plates is adjusted until no current is measured in the circuit.
15.6: Compton Scattering

tags.label: 15.6.A
tags.description: 15.6.A: Describe the interaction between photons and matter using the Compton scattering.

tags.label: 15.6.A.1
tags.description: 15.6.A.1: In Compton scattering, a photon interacts with a free electron. The Compton effect is when a photon that emerges from the interaction has a lower energy and longer wavelength than the incoming photon. The magnitude of the change is related to the direction of the photon after the collision.

tags.label: 15.6.A.2
tags.description:
15.6.A.2: Compton scattering provides evidence that light is a collection of discrete, quantized energy packets called photons.
  1. Compton scattering can be explained by treating a photon as a particle and applying conservation of energy and conservation of momentum to the collision between the photon and electron.
  1. The transfer of a photon's energy to an electron results in the energy, momentum, frequency, and wavelength of the photon changing.

Relevant equations:
\(\displaystyle{E=hf}\)
\(\displaystyle{\lambda =\frac{h}{p}}\)

tags.label: 15.6.A.3
tags.description: 15.6.A.3: The change in wavelength experienced by a photon after colliding with an electron is related to how much the photon's direction changes. Relevant equation: \(\displaystyle{\Delta \lambda =\frac{h}{{{m}_{e}}c}\left( 1-\cos \theta \right)}\)
15.7: Fission, Fusion, and Nuclear Decay

tags.label: 15.7.A
tags.description: 15.7.A: Describe the physical properties that constrain the behavior of interacting nuclei, subatomic particles, and nucleons.

tags.label: 15.7.A.1
tags.description: 15.7.A.1: The strong force is exerted at nuclear scales and dominates the interactions of nucleons (protons or neutrons).

tags.label: 15.7.A.2
tags.description: 15.7.A.2: Possible nuclear reactions are constrained by the law of conservation of nucleon number.

tags.label: 15.7.A.3
tags.description: 15.7.A.3: The behavior of the constituent particles of a nuclear reaction is constrained by laws of conservation of energy, energy-mass equivalence, and conservation of momentum.

tags.label: 15.7.A.4
tags.description: 15.7.A.4: For all nuclear reactions, mass and energy may be exchanged due to mass-energy equivalence. Relevant equation: \(\displaystyle{E=m{{c}^{2}}}\)

tags.label: 15.7.A.5
tags.description: 15.7.A.5: Energy may be released in nuclear processes in the form of kinetic energy of the products or as photons.

tags.label: 15.7.A.6
tags.description: 15.7.A.6: Nuclear fusion is the process by which two or more smaller nuclei combine to form a larger nucleus, as well as subatomic particles.

tags.label: 15.7.A.7
tags.description: 15.7.A.7: Nuclear fission is the process by which the nucleus of an atom splits into two or more smaller nuclei, as well as subatomic particles.

tags.label: 15.7.A.8
tags.description: 15.7.A.8: Nuclear fission may occur spontaneously or may require an energy input, depending on the binding energy of the nucleus.

tags.label: 15.7.B
tags.description: 15.7.B: Describe the radioactive decay of a given sample of material consisting of a finite number of nuclei.

tags.label: 15.7.B.1
tags.description:
15.7.B.1: Radioactive decay is the spontaneous transformation of a nucleus into one or more different nuclei.
  1. The time at which an individual nucleus undergoes radioactive decay is indeterminable, but decay rates can be described using probability.
  1. The half-life, \(\displaystyle{{{t}_{1/2}}}\), of a radioactive material is the time it takes for half of the initial number of radioactive nuclei to have spontaneously decayed.
  1. The decay constant \(\displaystyle{\lambda }\) can be related to the half-life of a radioactive material with the equation \(\displaystyle{\lambda =\frac{\ln 2}{{{t}_{1/2}}}}\).

tags.label: 15.7.B.2
tags.description: 15.7.B.2: A material's decay constant may be used to predict the number of nuclei remaining in a sample after a period of time, or the age of a material if the initial amount of material is known. Relevant equation: \(\displaystyle{N={{N}_{0}}{{e}^{-\lambda t}}}\) Derived equation: \(\displaystyle{\ln \left( \frac{N}{{{N}_{0}}} \right)=-\lambda t}\)

tags.label: 15.7.B.3
tags.description: 15.7.B.3: Different unstable elements and isotopes may have vastly different half-lives, ranging from fractions of a second to billions of years.
15.8: Types of Radioactive Decay

tags.label: 15.8.A
tags.description: 15.8.A: Describe the processes by which individual nuclei decay.

tags.label: 15.8.A.1
tags.description:
15.8.A.1: Some processes by which nuclei decay emit subatomic particles with unique properties.
  1. An alpha particle, or helium nucleus, consists of two neutrons and two protons and is symbolized by \(\displaystyle{\alpha }\) or \(\displaystyle{\text{H}{{\text{e}}^{2+}}}\). (In Physics 2, only He-4 nuclei will be considered.)
  1. Neutrinos and antineutrinos are subatomic particles that have no electrical charge, have negligible mass, and are symbolized by \(\displaystyle{\nu }\) and \(\displaystyle{\bar {\nu }}\), respectively.
  1. Neutrinos and antineutrinos only interact with matter via the weak force and the gravitational force, which results in very little interaction with normal matter.
  1. Positrons, or antielectrons, are subatomic particles that have an electric charge opposite that of an electron, have the same mass as an electron, and are symbolized by \(\displaystyle{{{e}^{+}}}\) or \(\displaystyle{{{\beta }^{+}}}\).

tags.label: 15.8.A.2
tags.description:
15.8.A.2: Nuclei can undergo radioactive decay via alpha decay, beta-minus decay (\(\displaystyle{{{\beta }^{-}}}\)), beta-plus decay (\(\displaystyle{{{\beta }^{+}}}\)), and gamma decay (\(\displaystyle{\gamma }\)).
  1. In all nuclear decays, nucleon number (the number of neutrons and protons), lepton number (the number of electrons and neutrinos), and charge are conserved.
  1. Alpha decay occurs when a nucleus ejects an alpha particle.
  1. Beta-minus decay occurs when a neutron changes to a proton by emitting an electron and antineutrino.
  1. Beta-plus decay occurs when a proton changes to a neutron by emitting a positron and neutrino.
  1. Gamma decay occurs after a nucleus has undergone alpha or beta decay and the excited nucleus decays to a lower energy state by emitting a photon.

tags.label: 15.8.A.3
tags.description: 15.8.A.3: The type of decay exhibited by a given nucleus is determined by the isotope of the element.

tags.label: Practice and Skill
tags.description: Practice and Skill

tags.label: Practice 1
tags.description: Practice 1: Creating Representations - Create representations that depict physical phenomena.

tags.label: 1.A
tags.description: 1.A: Create diagrams, tables, charts, or schematics to represent physical situations.

tags.label: 1.B
tags.description: 1.B: Create quantitative graphs with appropriate scales and units, including plotting data.

tags.label: 1.C
tags.description: 1.C: Create qualitative sketches of graphs that represent features of a model or the behavior of a physical system.

tags.label: Practice 2
tags.description: Practice 2: Mathematical Routines - Conduct analyses to derive, calculate, estimate, or predict.

tags.label: 2.A
tags.description: 2.A: Derive a symbolic expression from known quantities by selecting and following a logical mathematical pathway.

tags.label: 2.B
tags.description: 2.B: Calculate or estimate an unknown quantity with units from known quantities, by selecting and following a logical computational pathway.

tags.label: 2.C
tags.description: 2.C: Compare physical quantities between two or more scenarios or at different times and locations in a single scenario.

tags.label: 2.D
tags.description: 2.D: Predict new values or factors of change of physical quantities using functional dependence between variables.

tags.label: Practice 3
tags.description: Practice 3: Scientific Questioning and Argumentation - Describe experimental procedures, analyze data, and support claims.

tags.label: 3.A
tags.description: 3.A: Create experimental procedures that are appropriate for a given scientific question.

tags.label: 3.B
tags.description: 3.B: Apply an appropriate law, definition, theoretical relationship, or model to make a claim.

tags.label: 3.C
tags.description: 3.C: Justify or support a claim using evidence from experimental data, physical representations, or physical principles or laws.
